awd_titl_txt: Digitization TCN:  Collaborative Research: Capturing California's Flowers: using digital images to investigate phenological change in a biodiversity hotspot
awd_abstract_narration:
Flowering time is an important biological phenomenon, affecting human societies through its effects on agricultural crops, pollinators, pests, and biodiversity.  Given the sensitivity of flowering times to climatic conditions, a thorough understanding of how plants respond to changing environments is necessary for predicting the consequences for pollinators, herbivores, parasites, and plant populations.  A record of historical flowering times is found within the nation's herbaria.  This award establishes a thematic collection network (TCN) dedicated to understanding flowering time shifts in the California flora.  California has the most diverse native flora of any state in the U.S., containing more than one-third of all U.S. plant species.  The state is a biodiversity hotspot due to the high number of endemic species that are also threatened.  The Capturing California's Flowers (CCF) TCN will record flowering times from and create images of over 900,000 herbarium specimens from the oldest records, the most diverse families, and most threatened families in California.  Twenty-two institutions spanning the state, including public universities, state agencies, museums, and botanic gardens, will participate in these efforts.  This project will generate data that will increase our understanding of flowering time shifts - a critical need for agriculturalists, conservation biologists, plant taxonomists, land managers, and wildlife biologists.

Digitization of each specimen in the CCF TCN will result in a high-resolution image, a databased record of collection metadata, a georeferenced point, and the reproductive status of the specimen.  New tools will be developed for the public to search and display phenological data through a Symbiota portal interface.  The CCF TCN will develop novel data standards for capturing and sharing trait data from specimens.  Building on already successful national and regional programs, the CCF TCN will partner with schools, universities, botanical clubs, and the general public to crowd source phenological measurements through online expeditions, workshops, new college courses, and K-12 educational programs.  The CCF TCN will provide a historical record of plants currently being monitored through the National Phenology Network and other regional programs.  Finally, this award will expand efforts to train the "next generation" of museum curators, collectors, and researchers.  This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program, and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During the course of this project we imaged nearly 103,000 specimens of the nearly 300,000 in the UCR Herbarium.  All our specimen data and images are freely available and searchable by the public at the time of upload, which continues on a regular basis. Prior to the start of this award, our collection was nearly entirely databased, with the critical data on the flowering and fruiting condition of the specimen, as well as georeference data, already recorded.  The close assessment of our collection enabled by this award allowed us to identify specimens that had slipped through the cracks, and to database these as well, so that our collection is comprehensively recorded and the data publicly available online through the Consortium of California Herbaria portal (CCH2) and associated databases such as GBIF.  During the course of this project we continued to accession new specimens, which were immediately georeferenced and databased, with the data added to the CCH2 portal. We also used this deep dive into our collection to update nomenclature and reorganize taxa as needed.

The publicly available images allow us to develop a deeper and more comprehensive understanding of changes in flowering time in California due to climate change.   The data can be checked by others for errors because of the accessible nature of the platform.  Thus specimens that are misidentified or unidentified can be corrected to produce a more robust set of data.  These data will be used by climate scientists, farmers, land managers, conservationists, etc. in predicting plant phenological responses to climate. Our data specifically will contribute to understanding how California plants will respond to the dramatic changes occurring in our climate.  The UCR Herbarium has one of the strongest collections for southern California but we are also strong statewide notable for the central Sierra Nevada.

Imaging one-third of the specimens of the large and historic UCR herbarium has provided a critical resource for botanical researchers and educators. Some of UCR?s specimens date back to the mid-1800?s and were collected by important historic botanists and collectors including J.G. Lemmon, Marcus E. Jones, and Daniel Cleveland. UCR?s collections are worldwide in scope, including collections South Africa, the Middle East, and Australia; however, this grant largely mobilized UCR?s collections in Southern California, a highly variable and diverse region with many endemic species (Figure 1). Together, these data are being used by a broad community of researchers. According to GBIF, our data have been cited in over 420 publications or projects since October 2019 (https://www.gbif.org/dataset/e523cf2d-4fc2-48d8-aa75-80ecbc90b3f5).  Our data therefore contribute to a broad scope of scientific work that will likely increase as more specimens are digitized.

In spite of the covid shutdown, this project provided training for 1.5 permanent staff, 8+ volunteers, multiple injured workers on the Transitional Return to Work Program (through which injured workers, who are not able to perform their standard job tasks, work in the Herbarium until they are able to resume their job), 3 graduate students, and dozens of undergraduates. Approximately 70% of the students were female.  UCR is a Hispanic-serving institution, giving us the opportunity to introduce this under-served population to Herbarium work, plant diversity, and issues surrounding climate change and the local flora.  At least 7 of the students were Hispanic, and others include students of Filipino, Indian, and Korean backgrounds.  In addition, we had eight volunteers, three of whom were female and one of whom was Hispanic. The majority of the Transitional Return to Work Program staff are Hispanic.  These workers and volunteers were all trained in various Herbarium tasks and opportunities, exposing them to science that was new to them.  The undergraduate experiences ranged from Nights at the Museum, in which 5-10 students would spend several hours in the Herbarium learning curatorial methods, to students for course credit spending one or more quarters working 10-20 hours per week in the Herbarium digitizing, imaging, managing databases, and learning various curatorial methods from mounting to preparing specimens for loans.  Four students also participated in the CAP online digitization course. These students learned about herbarium specimens, digitization, California botany and geography, georeferencing, and using a database via this course.

Although this project has been completed, the UCR Herbarium continues to image our collection using the equipment purchased with these NSF funds, with the goal of barcoding and imaging our entire collection.  We continue to use the foundation provided by this funding to train students, Transitional Return to Work employees, graduate students, and volunteers.  We upload our data to the CCH2 portal on an ongoing basis, increasing the accessibility of our specimen data to the public and to researchers around the globe, so that our collection can contribute to our understanding of plant diversity and help generate solutions to urgent issues such as climate change, crop preservation, combating invasive species, and more.
